Kitchen Sink

Grid System

Twigkit uses a response 24 column grid system. The column widths are specified using a ratio of 24ths.

For example at the attribute sm="1-3" to the layout:block tag to set the width to 1/3 of the container width on small screens.

By default layout:blocks will be 100% width.


1 (Default) 23-24 7-8 5-6 4-5 3-4 2-3 1-2

Grid Breakpoints

Widths can be specified for each of the xs, sm, md, lg, and xl breakpoints individually.


Always full width xl=1-3, md=1-2 xl=1-3, md=1-2 xl=1-3, md=1

Grid Offsets

An offset attribute can be used to push the layout:block to the right, leaving an empty space


Always full width xl=1-3, md=1-2 xl=1-3 xl-offset=1-3, md=1-2 No offset md and above Offset at sm and above

Alignment Layouts

These three starter templates help create full width / partially centered / centered pages:

Full Width Hybrid Centered

Interruptor

I'm an Interruptor

Interruptors are smaller than banners, but larger than alertboxes.
They're about drawing your attention to a CTA of some sort.

Button

Alert Box

Did you mean the shop kitchensinks.co.uk? ×
Something you can probably ignore has happened. ×
Something bad has happened. ×
Something slightly worrying has happened. ×
Something good has happened. ×

Comparison Tables

Different options for displaying tables on small screens. In terms of css, examples 1 and 2 are identical. Example 3 stacks, so is perhaps unsuitable for comparisons. Example 4 is more of a hybrid that is in line with our original sketches. Examples three and four both rely on data-title for the labels.

Note: Tested in latest Chrome, FireFox, Safari and Opera. IE10 and above works. IE9 should be possible with some effort.

Table

  Henson Pictures Sony Pictures Warner Bros. Walt Disney Studios
URL henson.com sonypictures.com warnerbros.comdisney.com
CEO Brian Henson Thomas Rothman Kevin Tsujihara Alan Horn
Headquarters Los Angeles, California Culver City, California Burbank, California Burbank, California
Founded November 20, 1958 August 7, 1991 April 4, 1923 November 05, 1936
